text: If students do not eat out or usually eat out only at fast food restaurants, they might not be familiar with tipping. It might be useful to explain how that system works and even to work out one simple example as a whole class.
• Suppose you eat at a restaurant and the bill comes to $14. What would a tip of 10% be? A tip of 20%? A tip of 15%? ($1.40; $2.80; $2.10)
Following up on the strategies from Problem 3.1, you might ask:

• Can you show how to work out these tips on a percent bar? ((Step 1) A percent bar could be marked for 10%. (Step 2) Students can reason proportionally that 10% of $14 is $1.40 and (Step 3) then double this for 20%. (Step 4) Halfway between 10% and 20% is 15%. So, halfway between $1.40 and $2.80 is $2.10.)
• Can you show how to work out these tips on a rate table?
• Can you show how to work out these tips by writing a proportion?
Alert students that the questions here are about tips and discounts, but the same kind of reasoning as in Problem 3.1 will apply. Encourage them to use tape diagrams, rate tables, or proportions.
